div.p: Greetings. You have a living letter from our Zanchi.
Therefore, there is no need for more words.
You will understand from him what you wish to hear about Bernardino. He was with him in Basel.
What I have from Bern, I have enclosed here; but I would not want them to be spread; therefore, you will keep them to yourself.
I hear the last session was held on the day of the Conception of Mary, from which I conjecture that more were held this year than we have been able to attend.
Therefore, ensure that you encourage all friends to communicate to us what they receive from there.
I am surprised that I have not received any letters from you today; but I attribute this to your business.

Mr. Zanchi will be very useful to the church of God in those parts; but I fear that the papist adversaries will pursue him with all kinds of hatred and devise plans on how to expel him from the place.
However, the Lord is stronger than to be overcome by those talkers.
Return what I recently sent to you, especially the articles of Bernardino.
Live and farewell together with all yours.
Greet Mr. Consuls, Gallicius, and Pontasella. December 10, 1563.
To the most excellent man Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the church of Chur, my dearest brother.
